reviewText: This documentary is mostly strong. Using volunteers who monitored Fox "News" 24 hours a day for months, the film makers are able to discern and highlight several tactics Fox uses to portrary right-wing opinion as news. Although the film demonstrates conclusively that Bill O'Reilly is over-the-top and frequently plays loose with the truth, I doubt anyone will be surprised by the revelation. More disturbing are the more subtle ways in which Fox indoctrinates its viewers into believing things that are not true. For instance, the film exposes the frequent use of "People say..." as the introduction to assertions that don't meet anyone's criteria for news. The numerous former Fox employees who are willing to speak out are impressive, as are the comments from Walter Cronkite. In the end, Outfoxed overwhelmingly proves its thesis : Fox News is grossly misrepresenting itself to America when it claims to be fair and balanced. Fox, in reality, is neither. Nor is it news. BUT people watch Fox News to reconfirm what they want to believe. Fox could drop its misleading self-description and still have plenty of viewers; thus, this documentary is more about confronting Fox News' spin in an attempt at making the corporation responsible than about helping its willingly duped viewers. Nevertheless, it is a worthy goal. Finally, as much as I enjoyed the revealations about Fox News, the film does not merit five stars. The production values are mediocre; some hands are overplayed.

reviewText: Yes, it's no secret that Fox is unfair and biased instead of fair and balanced and is a very scary dispenser of radical right-wing propaganda, but this excellent documentary, contrary to what some detractors might suggest, does a lot more than just restating the obvious.  It gives many chilling and concrete examples of the different types of propaganda the channel uses, how it's run (scarily like Stalinist Russia, as seen in the examples of memos ordering people what to cover, and how, and the examples of people being screamed at and suspended if they didn't go along with the agenda, like what happened to Jon Du Pre when he didn't glorify Reagan's 90th birthday as something akin to a holy day, even though there wasn't a lot to cover), how they attack anyone who goes against their own radical ideology, how they were actually the ones who "called" the 2000 election even though it was still too close to call at the time, and how they consistently insert their own political beliefs in with the phrase "some say."  And this is far from left-wing propaganda.  The people who made the documentary may be progressives, but that doesn't automatically mean it's just the other side of the coin.  I would consider a radical leftist to do things like, say, use the spellings "Amerikkka" and "I$rael," or to be advocating anarchy, or to want to abolish the military.  All of the people interviewed in this documentary, a number of whom used to work for Fox, are very rational people who provide evidence for what they're talking about instead of frothing at the mouth with propaganda and rhetoric that's at the opposite end of the spectrum.There's also nothing wrong with the fact that Fox is a conservative channel with a consistently very conservative pov, since freedom of expression is one of our First Amendment rights and extends to everyone, not just people one agrees with.  The problem is with how they present these views.  Although I'm very left-wing, I know very well that there are a lot of intelligent conservatives out there, who calmly and maturely present their views and what they see as evidence to support these positions (as much as I disagree with them), who don't resort to bullying, childish name-calling, straw man arguments, fear-mongering, and outright lies to make their points.  A real conservative news network would have journalistic integrity, recognise that there's a conflict of interest if someone whose wife is covering the presidental campaign of the Republican candidate is himself covering that subject on the station, cover real issues instead of things that are either non-issues (since when does a silly story like "Bennifer" merit a news alert?!) or are designed to divide the people and divert attention from more serious things, not let their hosts constantly tell guests of opposing views to shut up and to label anyone who disagrees with them as enemies of the state, equally present both sides of an issue, not make the other side look ridiculous or like liars, while only showing their own people as demigods, have an equal amount of guests from each side, and have the panelists and hosts have equal credentials, instead of having their only "liberal" guests be very weak unknowns, conservatives in liberals' clothing, or someone like Alan Colmes, a pale squirrely-faced man who looks ridiculous when paired with a good-looking professional-looking guy like Sean Hannity.  As the documentary also says, the real truth should be arrived at after studying multiple points of view and going to multiple sources, instead of just getting all of your opinions from any news source, liberal or conservative, with such a demonstrated agenda and lack of journalistic integrity.Also included is a making-of featurette, featuring both the people who put the documentary together and the volunteers who watched Fox for 5 months to gather all of these chilling examples of disinformation, propaganda, and villification of anything that's not in line with the party ideology.  Unfortunately, this is one of those films that either won't be seen by those who most need to see it, or else is watched by said audience while covering their ears and shouting "La la la I can't hear you!"  And for those who do agree with the film's conclusion but continue to say "Who cares?" because Fox being right-wing propaganda is such common knowledge, as Jean-Jacques Rousseau once said, "As soon as anyone says of the affairs of the State `What does it matter to me?' the State may be given up for lost."

reviewText: In reviewing a DVD of this subject matter, it is hard to divorce one's critique of the movie itself from the basic agreement or disagreement with the subject matter. Given that and that I come from a perspective of general agreement that Fox is the antithesis of journalistic integrity, I have to concede that in many ways this is not a very tight documentary and lacks in many ways, quality in production and coherence.- The thesis of the documentary is never quite clear. While it seems to be that Fox News intentionally skews news to the right, the producers seem unable from avoiding wandering down paths such as pointing out that Fox is bad to its employees, that corporate control of the media is bad, and that Rupert Murdoch owns a huge media empire (including holdings in China).- There is no real active voice in the documentary (ie. no Michael Moore voice-over to guide you down a line of thought). Instead, a group of interviewee soundbites are clustered into categories of thought such as "Political Punditry" and "Some People Say." Within these categories, there is inconsistencies of thought and logic which makes it hard to understand the point the film is making.- The documentary takes some detours down some silly avenues which do not necessarily add to the thesis of the film. For example, an effective portion demonstrating a method which Fox anchors use to inject personal political opinion ("Some People Say") is followed by a segment dedicated to showing all the times that Bill O'Reilly has said "shut up." This is the exemplar of how the film alternates between illuminating points and simply demonstrating what we already know (ie. conservative commentators as a class skew towards the obnoxious end of the spectrum).- The interviewees are definitely of mixed caliber. They range from FAIR media and blogger types to former Fox employees to semi-celebrities including Al Franken and Walter Cronkite. The only elected official was Bernie Sanders. In the aggregate, they all were pretty far on the left. Some made good points; others less so. The best were when they stuck to investigating the thesis that Fox intentionally skews news to the right; the worst were when they cut loose on corporate ownership of the media.- The graphics and production were just not professional. The graphics looked like they were produced on powerpoint.- The conclusion of the documentary ("the call the action") is not articulated in a coherent manner. Rather, interviewees list possible solutions including "visiting the FCC" and "writing to Fox News affiliates." I suppose this may run counter to my original notion that the best way to silence idiocy is to ignore it, not to disallow it.I gave the documentary 3 stars because I thought it tackled an important and timely subject. As I mentioned above, I am in agreement with what the filmmakers are trying to say and truly wish I could have given it better rating. I hope that in the months to come, we will see tighter, more polished documentaries tackling this subject matter.
summary: An Interesting, but Ultimately Flawed Documentary

reviewText: Robert Greenwald, who directed the scathing documentary Uncovered: The Whole Truth about the Iraq War (2003) in which he demonstrated beyond any shadow of a doubt that the Bush administration repeatedly lied to the American people as it manipulated the Press and the Congress to get them to support its invasion of Iraq, now takes dead aim at one of Bush's most staunch supporters, media mogul Rupert Murdoch.Using the same technique that worked so well in "Uncovered," Greenwald plays clips from Murdoch's Fox News to show that Fox News is anything but "fair and balanced."  From the clips of Bill O'Reilly verbally abusing his "guests" and telling them to "shut up" to Brit Hume mouthing the Republican Party line in the guise of objective journalism to slanted stories directed from above (that would be from Mr. Murdoch himself in some cases, like some worshipful filler about Ronald Reagan or some non-news from Bush's standard stump speech) to the daily email directives telling the staff at Fox News how to slant today's selected  stories--from the glitz and the directive music and the flags in the background to the character assassinations of Republican opponents, to the "feel good" misinformation about the war in Iraq and Afghanistan, Greenwald shows that Fox News stands for propaganda, spoon fed to the American masses.Interspersed with the clips are sound bites from ex-Fox employees (some of them with their voices and faces disguised or hidden for fear of reprisals from Fox) and media experts and even some progressive politicians.  From the employees we get a glimpse of the stifling Fox News "culture" that subtly but unmistakably requires everyone on staff to slant the news as directed or find work some place else. What emerges is a portrait of a media empire that is dead set on destroying journalism as we know it.  And that's the way Murdoch wants it.  He wants to control events through the power of the media, to stifle contrary opinion and to keep the masses in couch potato ignorance.Thus there is a specter haunting the American democracy, and that specter is media control by anti-democratic corporations.  It is not just arch-conservative Rupert Murdoch and his vast media empire, it is CBS, NBC, ABC, CNN, etc. that are becoming more and directed from above, and more and more divorced from actual reportage in favor of the kind of spin and slant that pleases the corporate heads.  Even National Public Radio is coming under greater and greater corporate influence and control.What's to be done?We must elect public officials that will prevent the consolidation of media.  If we don't, those who own the media will soon own the government.  The airwaves belong to everyone.  No one should have a monopoly on their use.  Traditionally the media has served as "the Fourth Estate," a watchdog on government.  More and more it has abdicated that responsibility because its purse strings are controlled by its corporate sponsors.  In the case of Murdoch, more and more media is falling under the control of a single ideology.  Can a fascist state be far behind?I am not panicking yet.  The Democrats saw what can happen when the other side controls most of the media (almost all of it, actually), and fiscal conservatives are learning that social conservatives may not be their best allies, especially faith-based evangelicals whose first order of business is a return to ignorance and superstition on the way to establishing a theocracy in the United States like something out of Margaret Atwood's "The Handmaid's Tale."  As the mass mind becomes more and more dumbed down and indoctrinated into mindless consumerism while being massaged by a dictatorial media, greater and greater grows the threat to democracy.The real test will come after Bush is out of office.  The next administration must take steps to break up ClearChannel, etc., and prevent the further consolidation of Murdoch's empire.  The airwaves must be a public utility because to control media in the modern society is ultimately to control elections.This documentary is a clarion call to wake up and smell the newsprint because if Murdoch has his way there will only be the comic page and Murdoch-slanted news stories, editorials and canned opinion.
summary: On the growing threat from managed "news"

reviewText: First, an admission. The Fox News phenomenon is rather new to me. I haven't watched TV news in years, preferring to sift through the newspaper or the best I could find online from sources like Reuters and Associated Press. For me, the reason, outside of the annoying increase in commercials, was the endless parade of, "woe is me because the government ain't taking care of me" stories. Outside of headlines of the day, practically every "focus" story on the major networks had a definite left-wing bent. I couldn't stand the overriding feeling that I constantly was being told how I should think, or more accurately, that I shouldn't think at all. So I tuned out - and missed Fox's rise to fame or, I suppose I should say, notoriety.How surprised was I to skim through the channels and discover this upstart news channel that wasn't, well, boring! Flashy graphics, hot news babes and, best of all, people who weren't afraid to mix it up with their guests. No more pandering and slobbering on the mic (Larry King) to get a guest. If you started mouthing off, getting off track, or just being an idiot in general, they would flat-out tell you to shut up (O'Reilly). Sure, there was a definite right-wing slant, you'd have to be a moron not to realize that. Some are so far right they may have fallen off (Hannity). I didn't care. I was hooked! Then, slowly, after a couple of months of viewing, I started realizing something.Those on the right never, ever, lose.This was already in the back of my mind, but it never became clearer than at Fox's recent coverage of the Democratic Convention. Here sits Hannity with a stack of prepared talking points and reference notes while the supposed liberal, Colmes, has a post-it note or two containing some hastily scrawled handwriting. Colmes mutters something about not being ashamed to be a liberal. Hannity then proceeds to eviscerate not only Colmes, but three democratic pundits simultaneously. Sorry folks, but even at their own convention, the dems just couldn't compete.There's a reason why, and it's why you should watch Outfoxed.Outfoxed goes much deeper into the psyche of Fox News than just the flashy graphics and the right-wing agenda. Among the movie's claims, interviews appear to be legitimate or objective, while the graphics and headers on the bottom third of the screen often contain opinionated headlines. Off the cuff remarks are encouraged and any promoting the republican agenda or discrediting the democrats will get you the "atta boy" after the segment ends. Many internal memos obtained, while not necessarily incriminating, do reveal a definite agenda reporters needed to use on stories or when talking to guests.Even more interesting is Fox's use of the term, "Some people say..." While other journalists may say this in order to advance a storyline without revealing the source of the information. Fox uses the term liberally, (pardon the pun), so their reporters can insert political opinion instead of remaining objective. Of course you can gather which side of the political spectrum these opinions fall. As one writer explains, it's not necessary that Fox wins an argument. They simply need to muddy the argument to keep the viewer in a state of confusion. This way the viewer is unable to make a decision one way or the other which, to Fox, is as good as a victory.Most interesting, however, are the numerous times that people with a liberal agenda are simply outmatched. Again, there's a reason for this. After 25 weeks of study of the guests appearing on Special Report (Brit Hume) in 2003, 83% of the guests were republicans. On top of this, the liberals appearing repeatedly on the channel are usually "faux liberals" that often agree with the conservative side after some debate. Real liberals are rarely seen, intelligent liberals are rarely invited, and the ones who did put up a good argument are usually not invited to return. Fair and balanced?Finally, numerous ex-Fox employees testify of the almost crushing conditions they experienced while working there. In one hilarious segment, ex anchor Jon du Pre relates how he was suspended because he was unable to find anyone outside of a few people and a class of fourth graders celebrating Ronald Reagan's 80th birthday at his presidential library.Other reviewers have complained this movie is as much a propaganda piece as the news channel they're attacking. Frankly, they're right. Repeatedly, conservative media outlets like Fox and Clear Channel are railed against in this movie. Strange how no complaints were made against Viacom and Infinity (owners of MTV and Howard Stern.) The testimonies of so-called anonymous employees contain little credibility in my view. And, once you consider the backers and financiers of this film, the timing of this release during an important election is certainly no coincidence. As one writer correctly states, the reason why our propaganda system is vastly superior to the old Soviet-style propaganda machine, is we don't realize we are constantly being manipulated.If you get past the spin to the left, you get to the main reason why I recommend this movie. This movie made me see that media concentration is a worse problem than even I originally realized (and I consider myself a cynic and skeptic by nature.) I certainly don't want my news filtered by Murdoch any more than I want it filtered by Soros. Regardless of which side of the political spectrum you are on, the FCC's relaxation of limits on media ownership severely limits the information you receive, not to mention the quality of the information, so that you may form an objective opinion. How can you do this when independent publications keep getting silenced?Ok, I gotta run, Laurie Dhue's on. Hope the review helped.

reviewText: People who have already formed an opinion, and who are not open to any other viewpoint, should probably stay away from this documentary. It will either be "preaching to the choir"  or "liberal, left-wing lies," depending on the degree they hold fast to an opinion, despite evidence to the contrary. In short, they'll learn nothing because they already know "the truth." I've watched Fox News occasionally and simply find it less compelling and less professional than many alternatives.  It comes across like a tabloid versus, say, a well-put-together show like 60 Minutes. But, then, there are too many talking heads trying to fill too many hours of news programming. (We need more Walter Cronkite types and less news readers, who are often loyal to their employer's cause, whatever that might be.) So, we know Murdoch is conservative, that he has far too many media companies, that he has manipulated his empire to push a subtle, and sometimes not-so-subtle, agenda.  We know Bill O'Reilly is just a modern version of Joe Pyne and other loud-mouthed, opinionated, rude hosts. We know Sean Hannity is the attractive, preppy-looking one who makes the conservative point thereby seem correct, and that Colmes is a strange and poor excuse for the liberal point of view. (How about matching a Hannity type with Bill Maher or Michael Moore, not because those guys are male model types but because they can think on their feet and articulate their point of view effectively.) We know, alas, that the entire Fox package is one massive spin zone, and that most spin-meisters proudly speak of how they DON'T SPIN. . .which, if you think about it, is a very clever spin unto itself.  So, why does Fox News bother me?  Because as more and more people watch it, take it as gospel, and fail to see the Murdoch machine behind the scenes, they lose the real news in favor of a non-stop editorial.  If any one guy or any one company is allowed to monopolize the media---a trend I hope is severely curtailed in the near future---then we must seek out whatever variety of news and reportage we can to try to get the truth, minus the hot air.  (Watching BBC News, for example, gives us a unique view of our events from another country's perspective, which isn't a bad thing.) I enjoyed this documentary, recognized that it has a point of view that is anti-Fox, and tend to agree with it more than not.  But, I still enjoy watching O'Reilly once in a while, just as I listen to Rush once in a while:  not because I agree with them or like them; rather, because to discount how much power and influence they have is the ultimate head in the sand.  We'd all be better if our news were in the hands of a Walter Cronkite and a team like the 60 Minutes reporters. Meanwhile, this documentary has some compelling things to say about how information is presented, about corporate ownership and influence, and about our need to dig deep for the facts despite the non-stop barrage of "facts" presented by all the media.

reviewText: In 2003 the Program on International Policy (PIPA) released a study correlating people's understanding of world events with their primary news source. Comically, the study also found that people became more confused the more they paid attention to Fox.  So if you have to turn on Fox News, at least try to ignore it.To be fair (and balanced), the results of the poll didn't prove that Fox is actively trying to spread misinformation.  Defenders of Fox were quick to point out the theoretical possibility that people who are naturally confused are more drawn to Fox (possibly for its excellent coverage of car chases and animal attacks).And that's why Outfoxed is a valuable piece of journalism.  As many other people have pointed out, it's fairly obvious to any knowledgeable person that Fox slants their broadcasts to favor whatever nutty thing the Republican Party decides to do.  But Outfoxed gives us a glimpse of how the whole process works, including memos issued by the News Director and interviews with ex-employees of Fox News.  It's no longer possible to argue that Fox just happens to have greater appeal among clueless viewers.  On the contrary, Fox's propaganda is actively making people dumber. reviewText: Is Fox News a predictable reaction to the "liberal bias" that has supposedly existed over the last few decades, or simply another organization that has attempted to tap into the psyches of those who, like the followers of Rush Limbaugh, are fed up with "politically correct" thinking and long for diatribe that is free of the "tact and prudence" that frequently accompanies the reporting of news? It would be difficult to answer these questions without considerable scientific research, since one would have to find appropriate definitions of "liberal bias" and also appropriate measures of social dissatisfaction."Some people say" (no pun intended here) that this documentary was put together by those who are jealous of the monetary success of Fox News. This may be true, but the intentions and motivations of the producers of this work do not have any relevance to the truth of the content of it. Their motivations should be left to another study. The only thing that is relevant when analyzing a work such as this is to find out whether its content is factual and whether it can be checked by a curious and independent investigator.The producers do make an effort to document the events that they believe sheds light on the inherent "right-wing" bias of Fox News. For example, the give several examples on how Bill O'Reilly has bullied some of his "left-wing" guests on his show. They also give statistical evidence on how many Republican guests appear on Fox News versus Democrats, with a definite preponderance towards the Republicans. In addition, they interview several former Fox News employees, some of them on-camera and some of them anonymous, in order to allow the viewer to gain insight on what it was like to work at Fox News.However, no examples are presented that serve to counter the claims of these individuals or other evidence presented. To those who strive for objective studies of the news media, the inclusion of such examples would have been helpful, and would make a stronger case for the objectivity of the work. One of the most difficult things to accomplish when analyzing social phenomena is to remain objective and present both sides of an issue, in order to give a fair and balanced (no pun intended) view of it."Some people say", including this reviewer, that Fox News is an organization that is reeking with jingoism and fervent religiosity, and seeks to bolster the view of extreme forms of conservative thought. These are opinions, which again must be substantiated by careful scientific analysis. But Fox News is unlikely to change its attitudes, methodologies, and biases due to any criticism, whether from this work or any other. They will no doubt continue to act just as they have up until now. No penalty will result from doing so.

That's why DVD is the ideal format as some can simply pause when they start getting overwhelmed by the onslaught of facts, figures and testimonials by former Fox employees and even renowned newscasters such as Walter Cronkite. In fact, Cronkite says in the film that Murdoch never had any intention except to build a right-wing network, but that seems highly suspect given the aggressively posturing media stars that have risen since its debut. Unsurprisingly, Fox News' top host Sean Hannity comes across as an unmitigated bully, but Bill O'Reilly, arguably the network's biggest star, reveals himself in the film as someone with obvious issues around anger management and journalistic integrity. reviewText: We have something in this great country of ours called the Media.  It acts as something of a Fourth Estate, after the Executive, Legislative, and Judicial branches of our government.  But in recent years, the integrity of that Fourth Estate has been undercut by the agenda of a man named Rupert Murdoch, and a media outlet called the Fox News Channel.  And this is at the heart of Robert Greenwald's documentary OUTFOXED, which takes a look at the warping of our media by the first-ever cable news channel to clearly propagate a one-world viewpoint, one slanted very far to the right.Utilizing interviews with various former employees of the Fox News Channel, which, when it started in 1996, resembled in many ways Ted Turner's CNN at its 1980 start, OUTFOXED shows how Murdoch, who isn't even an American to begin with but was shown to be a fervent admirer of Ronald Reagan, began slowly but surely to undercut the media's ability to report on news stories accurately and with clear thinking in mind.  Bit by bit, it grew into a mega-media outlet with the power to influence people big time.  In every way possible, it became a television mouthpiece for the far right in America--a perfect example of 24-hour corporate cable fascism, where dissent was tantamount to treason, particularly after 9/11 and when it came to George W. Bush.Clip after clip after clip, we see the Fox News Channel's all-star lineup of blatant right-wing nutjobs--Bill O'Reilly; Brit Hume; Sean Hannity; Neil Cavuto--scathingly rip apart guests who disagree to any significant extent with them apart, while at the same time promoting their slogans of "Fair And Balanced" and "We Report, You Decide"--slogans which over time have clearly been shown, to say the least, blatantly untruthful.  And what is made dreadfully clear, especially in the clips of the FNC's "reporting" during the 2004 presidential election is of their certainity that Bush/Cheney were going to win, complete with the cheerleading.But apart from all this, OUTFOXED also says that the real sad thing is how other cable outlets have had to somehow use other TV personalities with right-wing proclivities to somehow "outfox" Fox, which is for all intents and purposes impossible.  This is a film as every bit as infuriating as FAHRENHEIT 9/11 was, if at a more sober key, and a very tragic commentary on how our system of government has allowed a Fox named Rupert Murdoch, and his cast of right-wingers, to run the henhouse that is the United States of America.But OUTFOXED also suggests that public outrage can bring about the change needed to stop other Rupert Murdoch types from hijacking America.  And that change seems to be slowly but surely taking place even today, making OUTFOXED a chilling and infuriating must-see film.
summary: The FOX Will Guard The Henhouse

reviewText: I'll admit that I've never been a fan of FOX news. The few times I've watched it, I've been annoyed by its glossy, glitzy sensationalist approach to the news. Well, so much for that--I prefer to get my news via the internet. But the documentary OUTFOXED from director Robert Greenwald argues that FOX news is more than just a tacky news programme. According to the filmmaker, the FOX channel--owned by right-wing media mogul Rupert Murdoch--pipes propaganda into millions of homes throughout the world.The documentary includes many interviews from former FOX television employees--some left, some were sacked, and some were eased out. But they all have the same story--participate in the party line, or you're out. Internal FOX memos are shown detailing how presenters are prompted to play up certain events and kill other stories. Various media watchdogs also appear--including Peter Hart from Fairness and Accuracy on Reporting (FAIR)--and these interviewees analyze the techniques FOX applies to its programming. And these techniques range from dirty (smear campaigns), nasty, hate mongering, and intimidation (Bill O'Reilly) to downright tricky. One of the best portions of the film shows O'Reilly 'interviewing' Jeremy Glick, the son of a man killed on 9-11. When Glick dares to voice an opinion, O'Reilly rudely shouts down his guest, and then subsequent footage show how the guest's comments were horribly distorted over an 11-month period.According to the film, FOX news has its share in the responsibility of the fear mongering that took place in the build-up to the war. As part of a concerted Strategy of Tension, FOX hyped fears. After watching some of the footage, I was surprised the news presenters didn't sink to wearing gas masks while on air. In one segment, a former CIA agent--a guest on FOX--tells host Hannity that he's concerned that America may have problems with wars on two fronts--Iraq and Afghanistan. Hannity makes an inane comment and compares this situation to walking and chewing gum at the same time. It's obvious that the guest's comments are being managed (cut) in a way to limit his point.But when one considers the responsibility FOX should have to offer accurate and fair news reporting, it makes me wonder how some people responsible for this nonsense can sleep at night. In one sequence, there's a news snippet stating that it's safer for soldiers on the streets of Iraq than it is living in California. I would have laughed out loud at this rubbish if it weren't so disgusting. (Earth-to-FOX news--no one in California has been blown up by IEDs.) But what's particularly upsetting is that millions of people who watch this stuff don't seem to realize that FOX has "eliminated journalism" and has instead become a mouthpiece for right-wing propaganda. According to one interviewee, FOX audiences tend to have comparatively "incorrect assumptions" about some of the myths of the Iraq war when compared to PBS/NPR audiences.On the down side, FOX television aficionados probably won't get much out of this documentary--whereas those of us who chose to not watch FOX will be appalled. But perhaps watching this documentary will help some of us Non-FOX channel people understand where some of the hare-brained brainwashing comes from when our neighbours and workmates begin to spout their propaganda--displacedhuman

reviewText: My initial reaction to "Outfoxed: Rupert Murdoch's War on Journalism" was that the thesis of Robert Greenwald's 2004 documentary was not really news to anyone.  A television news network does not get to be "Fair and Balanced" by its own admission any more than I buy at face value the claims made by commercials with regards to products or politicians with regards to their candidacies.  FOX News wanted to be the most conservative news network on television and had a clear shot at the title from Day One.  The great irony here is how FOX News has established enough weight, by virtue of their ratings success, to have other news networks gravitate towards the right.So "Outfoxed" is not so much an expose of intentions that are obviously blatant as it is a catalogue of techniques employed by FOX News to further its political agenda.  This consists of not only on air tactics, such as confronting targets with what "some say," but also management directives, such as the daily memos from corporate.  Greenwald mixes interviews with former employees of FOX News and other critics with a deluge of clips from its broadcasts.  If a directive comes down to push the idea that John Kerry looks "French," then we get a half-dozen examples of that being done on the air.  The basic approach here is to let the talking heads of FOX News hang themselves with their own words (e.g., Brit Hume points out that a soldier in Iraq has less of chance of dying than a random citizen of California has of being murdered, ergo, it is apparently safer for young men in California to join the army than to do anything else).Another irony of "Outfoxed" is that Greenwald uses some of the same disparaged techniques employed by his subject, particularly in terms of using music to set the tone for our approbation.  But this could just be another way of giving the devil his due.  There are times when Greenwald is having so much fun with the style that it detracts a bit from the substance.  I also think that one obvious antecedent for the tone and tenor of FOX News is ignored, and that would be "Crossfire," the celebrated CNN talking head show that I think is most responsible for bringing partisan incivility and outright rancor into the mainstream of television news.Ultimately the question with regards to "Outfoxed" is whether Murdoch's FOX News is preaching to the choir or actually converting the masses.  For example, there are some statistics showing that viewers who watch FOX News are several times more likely to hold specific beliefs in line with the position of the Bush Administration than those who watch the news on PBS.  I think that a large part of those numbers would fall in to the chicken and the egg category, which in this case would be conservatives and FOX News viewers respectively.  In other words, Murdoch is not so much creating conservatives as he is reinforcing their beliefs.  Granted, there must be some who are converted, but given the demonstrated bias of the network it is rather amazing that the figures supporting its positions are not even higher.The audience for "Outfoxed" is comparable to the electorate in 2004.  There will be those who will embrace it or dismiss it out of hand based on their ideological bent (and no doubt will write reviews accordingly), and clearly there are points where the attack can be considered hyperbolic (e.g, the idea that THE key factor in Bush's election was the decision of his cousin to have FOX News call Florida and the election, forcing the other networks to follow suit and establish the idea it was all over when it was really too close to tell).  But despite its attempt to retire fire in kind, "Outfoxed" is also informative in terms of detailing how Murdoch's organization comes about its business.  Whether this is a recipe for success or a sin against the canon of journalistic ethics will be up to the current generation of would-be journalists to decide.  Whatever else it may be, "Outfoxed: Rupert Murdoch's War on Journalism" certainly raises questions worth discussing in the classroom.

reviewText: Until recently, I thought of Fox only as the network that carried "The Simpsons."  Except on Election Night, I never watch television news for primary sources of information. Bush's first cousin John Ellis, who works for Fox, called the race for Bush.  The rest of the networks obediently followed the leader.This story, and much more, are highlighted in "Outfoxed."  The heroic task of watching Fox both live and taped, 24/7, over a period of months, and discerning the network's primary ways of slanting the news, was undertaken by a heroic crew of filmmakers and volunteers.  A large number of contemporary media critics and former Fox employees voice their opinions.  Even the unflappable Walter Cronkite says he's never seen the news slanted the way Fox does.The fact that the network does not rebut the argument during this film is irrelevant. These filmmakers have some 75 minutes to make their argument, and they do so most convincingly: that Fox does not "report" the news as journalists traditionally have done, that they package GOP talking points in red-white-and-blue bunting, and that what few "opposing  viewpoints" they do invite on air are cut off, muffled, or reviled.It is marvelous that new technology allows people who care to get their hands on films like "Outfoxed" without waiting to find out whether their local network, radio station, or movie theater is brave enough to show something controversial.

reviewText: Even though I'm an ardent hater of Fox News Channel, Outfoxed could have been much better for several reasons. First, there were obvious examples of Fox's conservative bias that the program missed (the way the studio audiences for Linda Vester's Day Side always deride liberals and applaud conservatives, the way every email comment put up before the commercial breaks on The Big Story with John Gibson always slam liberals and the way Hannity and Colmes always opens with Newt Gingrich, William Bennett or Ann Coulter, when they never have guests on like, say, Noam Chomsky or Michael Moore).Second, by having only liberal critics of Fox News Channel interviewed for the documentary, the documentary unwittingly gives credence to the conservative dictum that the mainstream media has a liberal bias (I put mainstream in quotes because more people watch Fox News Channel now than CNN or MSNBC combined -- therefore who is the real media elite now?). For instance, if director Robert Greenwald could have secured interviews with conservatives like William F. Buckley, Pat Buchanan, Matt Drudge or even William Kristol (who, because he is on the FNC payroll probably couldn't be asked), their views might have given this film more depth.Third, a consideration of how other news outlets operates is necessary to show just how different Fox News Channel is from CNN, MSNBC, PBS or the Network News on ABC, CBS or NBC. If, as certain people suggest, CNN is the Clinton News Network, how is their practicing of journalism any different from Fox's? The documentary makes too many assumptions about what constitutes objective journalism. It ends up sounding like liberal journalism (I mean, this documentary is funded by moveon.org). Does this mean that they want a model of news reporting that is simply the political opposite of Fox News, yet similar in tactical and practical approach (which this film is actually critical of)?Fourth, the film's supposed smoking gun evidence of Fox's Right Wing Conspiracy is interesting but hardly compelling. Memos from Fox News Executives are hardly earthshattering. But the interview the with the reporter hired to cover an underwhelming response to Ronald Reagan's birthday was very relevatory. He was suspended because he couldn't make a flashier story out of circumstances that really presented no interesting news story. The satellite-feed exchange between Carl Cameron (whose wife was campaigning for George W. Bush) and George W. Bush is also damning. Can you say conflict of interest? I knew you could. Also, the claim that Fox News basically won the election for Bush in 2000 is an interesting claim--though not nearly as cool as the one's devised by conspiracy theorists.Where the film succeeds is in its criticism of the channel's use of the phrase fair and balanced and in its assertion of being news. Now to be fair (ha-ha), if Fox would just admit to being a conservative news outlet, I would have no problem with them at all. Conservatives need a place to get the news they want to hear in a place where they feel comfortable. I understand that. But when they say fair and balanced yet 85 percent of the guests on Special Report with Brit Hume (that number is presumably higher on Neil Cavuto's shows) are Republicans, that seems pretty far from fair or balanced. (Also, the fact that FNC is, currently, airing very little of the Democratic National Convention gives credence to this film's claims.) The film does a good job of showing that the network has a strong roster of notable conservatives but a lackluster roster of liberals (who the hell is David Corn for instance). In this sense, Fox News Channel is only balanced if the conceit of a liberal media bias is seriously considered (i.e. FNC balances out fairness in coverage ideologically amongst the news outlets). On its own, though, it is hardly fair and balanced. As far as considering its network a news channel, Outfoxed also excels, but does not go far enough. Even though I don't trust FNC as a resource for getting news (I would rather watch MSNBC as far as TV is concerned), it is incredibly entertaining (watching CNN is unbearable: Aaron Brown is about as boring as watching a painting of a vase). Like conservative radio, FNC is chock-full of bullying personalities who spin opinions as news in a confrontational manner. No wonder people watch this stuff. It's fun, but it's hardly a way to get news.Though the film is filled with plenty cannon-fodder for any Fox News-hater worth his/her mettle, I just wish it was more rigorous in its examination of why Fox News Channel is so successful (in terms beyond those that are purely ideological).  Where it is successful is in its pessimism regarding the consequences of FNC's success on the world of news coverage in the West.

reviewText: While this excellent documentary falls just short of being outstanding, it is nonetheless a very helpful expose of the dubious and journalistically unethical practices that under gird Fox News's news reporting.  Actually, "news reporting" is one of the things Fox does not do.  As the documentary shows, Fox News, unlike other major news organizations, does not actually do much reporting, in the sense that they have few actual investigative reporters.  What they actually do is "re-reporting," usually taking news stories broken by others and then repackaging them to reflect a decided right wing bias.  What they report is only as accurate as the AP and Reuters feeds upon which they profoundly rely.As a news repackaging service, Fox has few parallels.  Actually, on a national scale on television, they have no parallels.  Although they have managed, along with other Right Wing organizations, to inject a right wing slant in most news reporting, other organizations like CNN and unlike Fox have a stable of field reporters, while Fox has primarily on air TV personalities who depend on the work of other organizations.  These reporters for CNN and other organizations try to present a reasonably unbiased account of the news.Much of what is contained in the documentary will be familiar with anyone who has even casually followed the media in the past decade.  It begins with the founding of Fox with the money of Rupert Murdoch as a means to place extreme Right Wing ideas inside a presumably unbiased news outlet.  Some time is spent on Roger Ailes, the lifelong GOP operative and media consultant who ran George H. W. Bush's 1988 presidential campaign, whose ties with the Republican party are deep and extensive, and who is the founder of Fox and the only head it has ever had.  The more depressing and chilling parts of the film are the interviews with current and past Fox employees, who detail the overwhelming right wing bias inside the organization, to the extent that onscreen language is organized to highlight or even create certain negatives about Democratic candidates, and killing any stories that would reflect badly on Republican ones.  Specific "talking point" memos are presented that paint a very negative picture of the journalistic ethics of Fox.  The most effective parts of the documentary are when such tricks are first stated, and then illustrated with five, ten, or twenty on air instants where a variety of Fox personalities hammer home that same point.  One such instance that I recalled was after Bush's State of the Union where he called for a second major tax cut slanted towards the rich.  Now, if asked to generate a list of words to describe that tax cut, "bold" is not likely to appear on anyone's list.  But within seconds of the end of the speech, GOP political figures and all of the on air personalities at Fox were describing it as a "bold" proposal.  In this way, Fox works hand in glove with the GOP to create an atmosphere of acceptance for GOP proposals.This points up the most dangerous thing about Fox: it is the only major news organization on television to have worked in concerted fashion with a political party.  Although claims in the past of a liberal biased in the media is demonstrably false (though it is one of the great achievements of the Right to have a so-called liberal bias to be taken as a commonplace), never was there the assertion that the Democratic Party (hardly itself a liberal organization, I'm unhappy to note--Bill Clinton, for instance, was to the right of Gerald Ford, Richard Nixon, and Dwight Eisenhower on most issues) actually colluded with any major news organization.  The daily collusion of Fox and the GOP is one of the great outrages in American political life.One of the more revealing bits in the film is when a reporter revealed that the organization tried to tout supposed celebrations of the birthday of Ronald Reagan.  The reporter went to the Reagan presidential library, found that there were no such celebrations, but was pressured to do the story anyway.  Viewers at home, however, could not know this.Unfortunately, the ones who most need to see this documentary are those who rely upon it for their news.  They assume Fox is a news organization, but as noted above, they don't actually do much in the way of reporting.  They re-report and repackage the news with a deeply biased, even propagandistic slant.  They decide, and they do not report, but the naive reporter is duped nonetheless.
summary: A solid expose of Fox News journalistic practices

Since most of America supposedly reads at a fifth grade level, that may explain their stunning success in everything from financial matters to swinging a presidential election by putting George Bush's cousin in charge of covering the event for Fox.  For people who have been in a coma for the past eight years or so this may be an eye-opening documentary, but for everyone else, this is two hours of obvious recapping, consisting exclusively of talking heads (mostly ex-producers and reporters) intercut with clips of Fox programs.  No new insights here, and Michael Moore did a better job revealing the general fiction of the "liberal media" in his Fahrenheit 9/11.  The present production is not a "bad" film, nor do I disagree with it; but if you're aware of Fox's bias you already know what you're going to see; if you're blissfully unaware, or have convinced yourself that this really is "journalism" or some sort of antidote for a supposedly liberal media, then your mind (what's left of it) won't be changed no matter what.  Also, the subtitle, "Rupert Murdoch's War on Journalism" is a little misleading.  It seems to imply the focus is on Murdoch when in fact he's touched on only slightly, and little about his life, his upbringing or his motivation is dealt with.  Overall, an unambitious piece on a tired topic.  It's nice that the "left" has begun to fight back, but they'll have to be more ambitious than this if they want to be successful.
summary: I agree with it, but it's nothing new or insightful

reviewText: Well, as I prepared to review this DVD, I looked at a few of the prior reviews. What a shock: so many who've never even seen it giving it one star with a bunch of nonarguments. Some things never change...especially the dry old claim that the mainstream media are bastions of the left. For those who claim that, prove it, or SHUT UP--to quote your mentor, Bill O'Reilly.O'Reilly is just one of the Fox demagogs this DVD covers. Now, I must admit that I've had a problem with the media for years. During Vietnam, few of the mainstream media pointed out the lies on which that conflict was based--until some of the editors' own offspring were getting killed over there. Then there was Desert Storm in which every VFW unit in the country was quoted, while voices challenging the invasion of Iraq were silenced. So my aversion to the "mainstream" started a long time ago. Then the "fairness doctrine" was eliminated. In fact, one of the talking heads in this DVD, a woman from Common Cause, said it was during the Reagan time that it was eliminated, but I recall it was actually during Carter. This permitted any mass medium to say whatever it would like--or whatever the "market" preferred. And that provided a fertile ground for things like Fox to thrive.I have a particular aversion to O'Reilly because my father-in-law worships him. Ironic, though, that my father-in-law reads O'Reilly's screeds without watching him intimidate and bully people on the air. When the son of a 9/11 victim signed a petition against the war, the O'Reilly staff hounded him until he finally came on. While the young guy was well prepared, O'Reilly did his best to bully him. Then when the kid essentially won, was prepared enough to do so, O'Reilly got the security guards to accompany him off the set, then the producer told the kid to get out of the building so that O'Reilly doesn't get violent with him. Oh, and that's on top of O'Reilly telling anyone who disagrees with him to "shut up!" and turning their mikes off. All of this is pretty well summarized in the DVD. (And I say the same thing I did in my review of "The Oh Really Factor" which I got from Amazon.com some time ago: To get that loud-mouthed bully off the air, refuse to appear on his show. Then he may have to go out and get a real job!)O'Reilly has the audacity to suggest on the air that anyone not supporting the war once we've bought into it is an enemy of the state? Hmmm...so Stalinist for a so-called conservative...Then there's Sean Hannity and his straight man, what's his name. More of the same rude behavior.Brit Hume. And others.Then there's the memos from the hierarchy telling them what they're supposed to report and how they're to report it. And they call that journalism...By the way, one of the commentators to which those who're fiercely critical of the DVD don't mention is that bastion of credibility Walter Kronkite. He too says he's never seen anything like Fox before in print or broadcast journalism. And most of the other commentators, the bulk of them former Fox reporters (many of them anonymous, with even their voices altered to maintain anonymity) criticize the "network" more for their phony claim to being "fair and balanced" than they do for being a "conservative network."Rupert Murdoch boasts of their "objectivity"; his lieutenant Roger Ailes says their plan is to ban excellent news organization. Yet, as the DVD shows, they're anything but that. All the traditional standards of journalism are ignored. There's no line between commentary and news. Even the "extra extra," a category intended for REAL big news, like school shootings, ends up being used for a showbiz marital squabble.One commentator called Fox "an adjunct for the GOP," and another had a nearly-as-poetic description. Fox's choice to portray everything Bush does as heroic, and everything John Kerry says as idiotic demonstrates that quite well. I only wish they'd done a little more work with refuting the claims. Like the words "flip flop" were repeated so often on anything Kerry said that one could get seasick hearing it. I wish they'd either demonstrated Bush doing that too--especially with the lack of eloquence Bush demonstrates so frequently unless he has an adolescent script before him--or refuted it, i.e., examined that what Kerry did was NOT a flip flop. (That's something  Al Franken, who appears in this DVD, did toward other victims of the mass media in his book which is also available from Amazon.com!)Before ending with a "what can you do?" section, most of the commentators state their fear that the problem with something like Fox is that it is influencing other networks. Flag-waving jingoism seems to have a market now, so that's the way the others are going. And that's dangerous. So much for a variety of honest, informed opinions.This is a powerful show, really. In fact, I intend to use it for "salons," discussion groups of people wondering what to do to make our society a better place to live. The last section I think is a little idealist, but I DO plan to contact the FCC and others. See this, and share it with others. And then let's start doing something about it.

reviewText: "Outfoxed" clears away the smoke and reveals the "fair and balanced" motto of Fox News to be an outrageous sham.  Early in this fast-paced and highly informative documentary produced and directed by the talented Robert Greenwald, Fox star commentator Neil Cavuto exclaims, " ... if, God forbid, John Kerry is elected president."The Cavuto comment makes one laugh robustly at any "fair and balanced" claim in the wake of that revelation and much more, such as the harangues of rightist stalwarts such as Sean Hannity and Bill O'Reilly.  It also tempts one to play the game of "if the shoe were on the other foot" regarding the right and Cavuto's statement.What type of response would be generated by the right and, through the swift ripple effect, the entire media if Dan Rather were ever to state on CBS, " ... if, God forbid, George Bush is victorious in the presidential election"?  How long would it take for the vigilante posse to be formed and the gallows to be erected in the center of town?  This would be the most calamitous outrage since the uproar over Bill Clinton having extra-marital sex with an intern.The documentary's informative value is enhanced by the appearance of ex-Fox employees explaining company policies.  One former executive recalls fondly the good old days in the network's early period.  Australian media mogul Rupert Murdoch gave his reporters and commentators the opportunity to function on their own without the intervening look over the shoulder from Big Brother.That early period soon shifted abruptly to the pattern that has unfolded thereafter, one of Murdoch imposing his pronounced right wing views and the network becoming an adjunct of the Republican Party.  Memos would be presented with talking points for the day established.  Generally they would consist of either making a particular liberal Democrat look bad or the Bush White House look good, or both.One sees that the view adopted by some of certain liberals being wimps and wilting under intense right wing heat is not the major factor where Fox is concerned; power lies with the microphone and blustery Bill O'Reilly is a classic example of taking advantage of corporate advantage.  The lesson to be learned at Fox and elsewhere is that power resides with control of the microphone, and with it the network.O'Reilly controls a tight mike.  When he is pushed hard his voice notably rises and he becomes flustered.  If the tide is not swiftly turned and his adversary continues to pummel the position he advocates the interview is terminated.  A classic instance was when young Jeremy Glick, whose father worked for the New York Port Authority and died in the September 11 tragedy, appeared as a well-informed guest who had closely studied O'Reilly's interview pattern beforehand.When a coolly confident Glick told O'Reilly what he thought about the Bush administration action of bombing Afghanistan in the manner that it did, killing peasants rather than terrorists, the blustery host began shouting and ultimately called for security guards to escort his guest out of his interview room.  Glick explained that, after he went to obtain a cup of coffee in an anteroom a few feet away, concerned security guards asked him to leave for fear that O'Reilly might strike him and would be sent to jail.Another Fox pattern was exposed in this illuminating documentary.  When commentators receive their talking points they are instructed to repeat certain words as part of a mantra designed obviously to brainwash under the guise of providing information to viewers.  The expression "some people are saying" is used as a preface for a leading comment, either supporting a Republican position or hammering Democrats.  Over the course of time, according to the strategy, the sayings will stick and become imbedded thought patterns as well as perhaps part of that individual's lexicon."Outfoxed" reveals the dangers of corporate power immersed in the clutches of a Rupert Murdoch with the means of delivering propaganda broadcasts on behalf of the Republican right while operating under the pretense of "fair and balanced" coverage.Also revealed is the episode from election night 2000 when George W. Bush's first cousin John Ellis declared the then Texas governor to be the winner.  This launched a stampede of other news organizations, giving the Republicans the huge advantage of being perceived winners when the bitter Florida Recount battle began.
summary: Rupert Murdoch's Republican Spin Machine Exposed
